study_goal: The researchers aimed to characterize the acute effects of Finnish sauna bathing on circulating markers of inflammation in healthy middle-aged and older adults.
results_summary: The study found that two 10-minute sauna sessions increased IL-6 levels, while both one and two sessions increased IL-1RA levels. CRP levels remained unchanged after sauna sessions.
population_specificity: Healthy middle-aged and older adults (9 men/11 women, 66 ± 6 years old).
effective_dosage: 1 x 10-minute session and 2 x 10-minute sessions at 80°C and 20% humidity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if intermittent post-exercise sauna bathing improves exercise heat tolerance and performance markers in temperate conditions compared to endurance training alone, and whether longer sauna use (7 weeks) further enhances heat tolerance.
results_summary: Sauna bathing over three weeks significantly improved heat tolerance (reduced peak rectal temperature, skin temperature, and heart rate) and exercise performance (increased VO2max and speed at 4 mmol/L blood lactate). Extending sauna use to seven weeks only marginally improved rectal temperature further.
population_specificity: Twenty middle-distance runners (13 female, mean age 20 ± 2 years, VO2max 56.1 ± 8.7 ml/kg/min).
effective_dosage: 28 ± 2 minutes post-exercise sauna bathing (101-108°C, 5-10%RH), 3 ± 1 times per week.
study_duration: 3 weeks (primary intervention), with 6 participants continuing for 7 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a micro-sauna prototype to deliver heated air (80-90°C) as a potential treatment for COVID-19 by destabilizing viral pathogens.
results_summary: The study described the engineering of a micro-sauna prototype capable of safely delivering heated air, but no clinical efficacy data on COVID-19 treatment were provided.
population_specificity: Not specified (prototype development only).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of sauna treatment in improving cardiovascular function, focusing on both acute and short-term effects.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in cardiovascular metrics such as blood pressure, heart rate, left ventricular ejection fraction, and physical activity levels, particularly in patients with lower cardiovascular function. Both acute and short-term sauna treatments showed statistically significant benefits.
population_specificity: Patients with cardiovascular function concerns, including those with lower left ventricular ejection fraction and New York Heart Association class III and IV.
study_duration: Acute effects (0-30 min post-sauna) and short-term effects (2-4 weeks following treatment)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of repeated Finnish sauna baths on nitric oxide metabolites, oxidative stress markers, and antioxidative status in young males with varying physical activity levels.
results_summary: The study found that repeated sauna baths improved the pro-oxidative/antioxidative balance, increased nitric oxide production, and reduced oxidative stress markers, particularly in physically active individuals.
population_specificity: Healthy young males aged 20-25 years, divided into training (N=10) and non-training (N=10) groups.
effective_dosage: 10 sauna baths over 3 weeks, each consisting of three 15-minute sessions with 2-minute recovery intervals.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether dry sauna therapy improved the quality of life in obese individuals.
results_summary: Dry sauna significantly improved health-related quality of life scores (EQ-5D and EQ-VAS) but did not significantly affect body mass index, blood pressure, heart rate, or body composition. No adverse events were reported.
population_specificity: Obese adults (BMI ≥25 kg/m²), predominantly female (84.2%), average age 62.3 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the acute effects of sauna bathing on recovery of swim performance following an intensive training session.
results_summary: Sauna bathing led to significantly worse swim performance the following day compared to the placebo condition, with a notable decline in the first 50 meters. Subjective stress levels were also higher after sauna use.
population_specificity: 20 competitive swimmers and triathletes (3 female, 17 male) with at least 2 years of national-level competition experience.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether dry sauna therapy improves quality of life and reduces pain in patients with low back pain.
results_summary: Dry sauna therapy significantly reduced pain (VNRS) and disability (ODI) scores, with 70% of participants reporting successful treatment and no adverse effects observed.
population_specificity: 37 patients over 20 years of age with low back pain.
effective_dosage: 15-minute sessions twice daily for 5 consecutive days (total 10 sessions) at 90°C.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether sauna yoga at 50 °C improves flexibility, strength, balance, and quality of life in healthy elderly individuals.
results_summary: Sauna yoga significantly improved flexibility (chair sit-and-reach test) and balance (eyes closed), with modest improvements in lower extremity strength and environmental quality of life. Strength and balance showed trends but no statistically significant benefits from the sauna environment.
population_specificity: Healthy elderly community dwellers (mean age ~69 years).
effective_dosage: Moderate temperature sauna (50 °C) during yoga sessions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the physiological effects and thermal comfort of dry and wet sauna baths on young healthy women, assessing changes in indicators like body weight, blood pressure, heart rate, and thermal sensation.
results_summary: The study found that wet sauna bathing caused greater physiological strain (higher rectal temperature, heart rate, and thermal discomfort) compared to dry sauna, though both increased systolic blood pressure and decreased diastolic blood pressure. Weight loss was significantly higher after dry sauna sessions.
population_specificity: Ten young healthy women aged 22-24 years.
effective_dosage: 60-minute sauna sessions (3x 15-minute exposures with 5-minute cooling intervals) in both dry (91°C, 18% humidity) and wet (59°C, 60.5% humidity) conditions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the prospective association between the frequency of Finnish sauna bathing and the risk of all-cause and site-specific cancers in a middle-aged male population.
results_summary: The study found no significant association between frequent sauna bathing (2-3 or ≥4 sessions per week) and the risk of all-cause or site-specific cancers (prostate, gastrointestinal, lung) compared to ≤1 session per week. The findings were consistent but non-significant across multivariate-adjusted analyses.
population_specificity: Middle-aged Caucasian men (42-61 years) with no history of cancer.
effective_dosage: 2-3 sessions per week and ≥4 sessions per week (compared to ≤1 session per week).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the acute effects of sauna bathing on heart rate (HR) and heart rate variability (HRV) as indicators of autonomic nervous system activity.
results_summary: A single sauna session significantly altered HRV variables, transiently reducing vagal activity during the session but increasing parasympathetic activity during recovery. Resting HR decreased post-sauna, suggesting favorable autonomic nervous system modulation.
population_specificity: 93 participants (mean age 52.0 years, 53.8% male) with cardiovascular risk factors.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of sauna bath, particularly infrared sauna, on cardiac function in heart failure (HF) patients.
results_summary: Infrared sauna bath (60°C for 15 minutes, followed by 30-minute rest) five times a week for 2-4 weeks significantly improved B-type natriuretic peptide levels, cardiothoracic ratio, and left-ventricular ejection fraction, but had no significant effect on other cardiac parameters. The evidence strength varied from moderate to insufficient.
population_specificity: Patients with heart failure (HF).
effective_dosage: 60°C for 15 minutes, followed by 30-minute rest, five times a week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the demographics, motivations, and health experiences of regular sauna bathers globally, focusing on perceived benefits and adverse effects.
results_summary: The study found that sauna-bathing was primarily used for relaxation, stress reduction, and pain relief, with 83.5% reporting sleep benefits and some improvements in mental well-being for frequent users. Adverse effects were mostly minor, though two severe cases requiring hospitalization were noted.
population_specificity: Predominantly well-educated, non-smoking, regularly-exercising individuals of normal-to-overweight status from Finland, Australia, and the United States.
effective_dosage: Approximately 1-2 times per week (varies by group: <5, 5-15, >15 times per month).
study_duration: Data collected from October 2016 to October 2017 (1 year).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and preliminary health benefits of a sauna detoxification regimen for individuals in substance abuse treatment.
results_summary: The sauna regimen was well tolerated with a 99% completion rate, no serious adverse events, and statistically significant improvements in mental and physical health scores. Client-reported satisfaction was high, and improvements were noted in addiction severity and overall well-being.
population_specificity: 109 individuals in a long-term residential substance abuse treatment program, including some with HIV or hepatitis C.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of sauna bathing on physiological parameters in young, overweight, sedentary men and to test correlations between these parameters and anthropometric/body composition features.
results_summary: The study found significant increases in physiological parameters (heart rate, energy expenditure, blood pressure, and body mass loss) during successive sauna sessions, with the strongest correlations observed in men with higher obesity and larger body size. A 60-minute sauna treatment resulted in a notable reduction in body mass (0.65 kg).
population_specificity: Young (20.76±2.4 y), overweight, sedentary men.
effective_dosage: Four 10-minute sauna sessions (90-91°C, 14-16% humidity) with four 5-minute cool-down breaks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the feasibility of HIV testing, counseling, and linkage to care among men who have sex with men (MSM) in a gay sauna setting in Thailand.
results_summary: The study found that active targeted HIV testing and counseling was feasible among MSM in the sauna, with 17% of participants testing positive for HIV. However, false perceptions of low HIV risk and poor linkage to care were significant barriers.
population_specificity: Men who have sex with men (MSM) aged ≥18 years attending a gay sauna in Thailand.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the short-term effects of sauna bathing on arterial stiffness and haemodynamics in individuals with cardiovascular risk factors.
results_summary: Sauna bathing reduced pulse wave velocity, blood pressure, mean arterial pressure, and left ventricular ejection time immediately after the session, with some effects sustained during recovery. Heart rate increased post-sauna, but no significant changes were observed in augmented pressure or pulse pressure amplification.
population_specificity: 102 asymptomatic participants with at least one cardiovascular risk factor (mean age 51.9 years).
effective_dosage: Single sauna session (30 minutes at 73℃ with 10-20% humidity).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the prevalence, habits, and health-related quality of life (HRQoL) associations of sauna bathing among very old men.
results_summary: Regular sauna bathing was common among octogenarian men and associated with better HRQoL, particularly in physical function, vitality, social functioning, and general health. However, nearly half of the cohort reduced sauna use due to nonspecific reasons, mobility problems, or health concerns.
population_specificity: 524 mostly home-living men aged 80-95 years from the Helsinki Businessmen Study.
effective_dosage: Median time in the hot room was 15 minutes at 80°C, mostly once a week (10% bathed more than twice a week).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate changes in cardiac parameters (arterial blood pressure, pulse frequency, and body temperature) after a single sauna bathing intervention in healthy young adults.
results_summary: The study found a statistically significant increase in arterial blood pressure, pulse frequency, and body temperature after sauna bathing, though these changes remained within physiological norms. Values returned to baseline after body chilling and a 20-minute rest.
population_specificity: 44 healthy young adults (22 men and 22 women) aged 20-25 years with no history of respiratory or circulatory system illnesses.
effective_dosage: Sauna temperature at 110°C with 15% humidity; refreshing shower at 16-18°C.
study_duration: Single sauna bathing intervention with measurements taken before, immediately after, and after 20 minutes of rest.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of a combined therapy (EMMS) including sauna for reducing pain, improving physical function, and enhancing quality of life in a patient with rheumatoid arthritis.
results_summary: The study found that EMMS therapy, including sauna, reduced pain, depression, anxiety, and stress while improving physical function, sleep quality, and overall quality of life in the patient. No side effects were reported.
population_specificity: A 48-year-old woman with rheumatoid arthritis.
effective_dosage: 3 sauna sessions of 15 minutes each over 3 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine whether regular sauna bathing could reduce pain intensity in patients with chronic tension-type headache (CTTH).
results_summary: The study found that sauna bathing significantly reduced headache intensity compared to the control group, but there were no significant changes in headache duration, sleep, depression, or disability scores.
population_specificity: Thirty-seven individuals diagnosed with CTTH according to International Headache Society criteria.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether combining repeated sauna therapy with exercise training improves symptoms, cardiac function, daily activities, and ambulation capacity in chronic heart failure patients.
results_summary: Both sauna therapy alone and combined with exercise training significantly improved cardiac function, daily activities, and ambulation capacity, with the combined therapy showing higher statistical significance in some outcomes. The study concluded that combining exercise training with sauna therapy may be more effective for improving cardiac function and daily activities in these patients.
population_specificity: 54 patients with chronic heart failure (26 in combined therapy, 28 in sauna monotherapy).
effective_dosage: Sauna therapy and exercise training once a day, 5 days a week.
study_duration: From hospital admission to discharge (exact duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of Finnish sauna bathing on lipid profile in healthy, young men.
results_summary: The study found a statistically significant decrease in total cholesterol and LDL cholesterol during and after the sauna sessions, a transient decline in triacylglycerols, and a slight but insignificant increase in HDL cholesterol. The effects on lipid profile were similar to those achieved through moderate-intensity physical exercise.
population_specificity: Healthy, young men aged 20-23 years.
effective_dosage: 10 sauna sessions, each consisting of three 15-minute parts with 2-minute cool-downs between them, conducted every 1 or 2 days.
study_duration: 3 weeks of sauna treatment plus follow-up measurements in the weeks after.

study_goal: The researchers reported a rare case of non-exercise-induced heat stroke in a 73-year-old male after prolonged sauna exposure, aiming to highlight the risks and management of such incidents.
results_summary: The study found that prolonged sauna exposure led to acute liver failure and heat stroke in the patient, who was successfully treated with high-volume plasma exchange and recovered completely.
population_specificity: 73-year-old male with prolonged sauna exposure.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the antioxidant status and adaptive physiological responses in volunteers before and after infrared sauna exposure.
results_summary: The study found that high temperatures initially induced oxidative stress but subsequently activated antioxidant defenses, improved cellular responses, and enhanced vascular function. These adaptive reactions suggest a stimulatory effect on the body's protective mechanisms.
population_specificity: Volunteers (specific demographics not detailed in the abstract).
study_duration: Not specified (referred to as "a course of general infrared irradiation").

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Waon (low-temperature sauna) therapy could improve myocardial perfusion in patients with ischemia related to chronic total occlusion (CTO) of coronary arteries.
results_summary: Waon therapy significantly improved myocardial perfusion (reduced summed stress and difference scores), extended treadmill exercise time, and enhanced vascular endothelial function, though it slightly decreased circulating CD34-positive cells. The control group showed no changes.
population_specificity: 24 patients with ischemia in CTO-related coronary artery areas.
effective_dosage: 60 °C far infrared-ray dry sauna bath for 15 min daily, followed by 30 min in a bed covered with blankets.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether a sauna detoxification protocol could alleviate chronic symptoms and improve quality of life in law enforcement officers exposed to methamphetamine-related chemicals.
results_summary: The study found statistically significant improvements in health evaluations (SF-36), symptom scores, and neurotoxicity scores, with a high completion rate (92.8%), suggesting the protocol was effective and well-tolerated.
population_specificity: Utah police officers with employment-related methamphetamine exposures and chronic symptoms.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety, efficacy, and health benefits of sauna therapy, particularly for conditions like hypertension, heart failure, and environmental illness.
results_summary: The study found that sauna therapy is effective for hypertension, congestive heart failure, post-myocardial infarction care, and some chronic conditions like COPD and chronic pain. It also supports sauna use in depuration protocols for environmentally-induced illness, though early pregnancy use may pose risks.
population_specificity: Individuals with hypertension, congestive heart failure, post-myocardial infarction, COPD, chronic fatigue, chronic pain, addictions, and environmentally-induced illness.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the mechanisms by which repeated sauna therapy (Waon therapy) improves cardiac function and exercise tolerance in patients with chronic heart failure.
results_summary: Waon therapy significantly improved left ventricular ejection fraction, reduced plasma levels of norepinephrine and brain natriuretic peptide, increased 6-minute walk distance, enhanced endothelial function (FMD), and raised circulating CD34(+) cells. These improvements were correlated with better exercise tolerance and peak Vo(2).
population_specificity: 41 patients with chronic heart failure (mean age 68.3 ± 13.5 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether thermal therapy combining sauna and underwater exercise improved pain, symptoms, and quality of life in fibromyalgia syndrome (FMS) patients.
results_summary: The study found significant reductions in pain and symptoms (31-77%) after a 12-week thermal therapy program, with sustained improvements (28-68%) during a 6-month follow-up. Quality of life also improved, as measured by SF-36 scores.
population_specificity: 44 female FMS patients meeting ACR criteria.
effective_dosage: Sauna therapy once daily for 3 days/week and underwater exercise once daily for 2 days/week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether repeated sauna therapy (ST) could increase coronary vascularity and attenuate cardiac remodeling after myocardial infarction (MI) in rats.
results_summary: ST reduced left ventricular dimensions, attenuated increases in LV end-diastolic pressure, decreased cardiomyocyte cross-sectional areas, and improved coronary vascularity in noninfarcted myocardium, associated with increased eNOS and VEGF mRNA levels.
population_specificity: Wistar rats with induced myocardial infarction.
effective_dosage: 15 min at 41°C followed by 20 min at 34°C, once daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of inhaling hot dry air (sauna) versus room-temperature dry air on symptom severity in patients with the common cold.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in overall symptom severity between the groups, but there were significant differences in medication use on Day 1, symptom severity on Day 2, and perceived therapy effectiveness on Day 7.
population_specificity: 157 patients with symptoms of the common cold in Berlin, Germany.
effective_dosage: Not specified (intervention involved inhaling hot dry air in a sauna).
study_duration: 3 days of treatment with a 4-day follow-up.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of six weeks of repeated sauna treatment on autonomic nervous system function, peak nasal inspiratory flow (PNIF), and lung function in Thai patients with allergic rhinitis.
results_summary: The study found that six weeks of sauna treatment significantly increased sympathetic activity (higher LF/HF ratio), improved PNIF, and enhanced lung function (FEV1) compared to the control group.
population_specificity: Thai patients with allergic rhinitis (26 participants, 12 males and 14 females).
effective_dosage: 30 minutes per session (6 sets of 5 minutes each, alternating with 5-minute rest periods), 3 days per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to describe the characteristics and treatment of burn injuries caused by hot air sauna burns in a specific population.
results_summary: The study found that sauna air can cause deep burns penetrating all skin layers, leading to necrosis and rhabdomyolysis, with third-degree burns developing rapidly. Treatment involves preventing kidney damage and surgical intervention, including local flaps for tissue defects.
population_specificity: Middle-aged men who passed out on sauna benches under the influence of alcohol.
interactions: Alcohol mentioned as a contributing factor.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to describe a severe case of heat stroke resulting from sauna use and its clinical outcomes.
results_summary: The study reported a case of severe heat stroke with 20% 2nd degree burns, multi-organ failure, and critical polyneuropathy following sauna exposure, highlighting its grave prognosis.
population_specificity: A single patient with severe heat stroke from sauna use in Denmark.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the potential mechanisms by which sauna therapy may increase BH4 availability and its implications for treating diseases associated with BH4 deficiency.
results_summary: The study suggests sauna therapy may increase BH4 availability through increased vascular shear stress and Hsp90 induction, potentially benefiting conditions like hypertension, vascular dysfunction, and chronic fatigue syndrome. However, no direct clinical evidence is provided to confirm these effects.
population_specificity: Not specified (theoretical mechanisms discussed, not a clinical population).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the unique characteristics and treatment challenges of hot air sauna burns (HASBs) and share their department's experience in managing these injuries.
results_summary: The study found that HASBs involve deep tissue damage and require aggressive early surgical intervention, including amputations and flap coverage, due to concurrent rhabdomyolysis. Treatment differs significantly from other burn types, with pedicled flaps being preferred over microvascular free flaps.
population_specificity: Patients with hot air sauna burns (42 cases recorded in literature).

study_goal: To assess the safety and acceptance of supervised sauna bathing at moderate temperatures in people with chronic heart failure (CHF) and its impact on exercise tolerance and neuroendocrine concentrations.
results_summary: Sauna bathing was well tolerated with no adverse effects. Improvements in quality of life and exercise endurance were noted but not statistically significant between groups; neuroendocrine changes were minimal except for a 24% decrease in noradrenalin.
population_specificity: Nine individuals (6 men, 3 women, aged 62-87) with New York Heart Association Class III and IV CHF.
effective_dosage: 15-minute sessions (extended to 20 minutes if oral temperature increased less than 1.0°C), 3 times per week at 60±1°C.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of infrared sauna therapy on pain, stiffness, fatigue, and disease activity in patients with rheumatoid arthritis (RA) and ankylosing spondylitis (AS).
results_summary: Infrared sauna therapy significantly reduced pain and stiffness during sessions (statistically significant) and showed clinical improvements in pain, stiffness, and fatigue over the 4-week period, though these were not statistically significant. No adverse effects or disease exacerbation were reported.
population_specificity: 17 RA patients and 17 AS patients.
effective_dosage: Eight infrared treatments over 4 weeks (frequency not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the potential of sauna bathing as part of a rehabilitative treatment to aid in the elimination of lipophilic chemicals and drugs from body stores.
results_summary: The study suggests that sauna bathing, combined with exercise and vitamin/mineral supplementation, may improve symptoms related to chemical exposure and drug addiction, though long-term effects remain largely unknown.
population_specificity: Individuals undergoing drug rehabilitation or exposed to lipophilic chemicals (broadly described, not specified in detail).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the influence of repeated sauna baths on fat metabolism in young women.
results_summary: The study found that repeated sauna baths accelerated lipid metabolism, reduced total cholesterol and LDL levels, and increased HDL levels. These changes suggest potential benefits for ischemic heart disease prevention.
population_specificity: 20 healthy, eumenhorreic young women aged 19-21 years.
effective_dosage: Group I: 30-minute sauna sessions; Group II: 40-minute sauna sessions with a 5-minute break, both every second day.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate a case of hypersensitivity pneumonitis linked to exposure to a contaminated steam bath.
results_summary: The study identified Exophiala jeanselmei as the causative agent in a steam bath environment, leading to hypersensitivity pneumonitis in a patient. The patient recovered fully after corticosteroid treatment and cessation of exposure.
population_specificity: A 55-year-old man with symptoms of cough and dyspnoea after regular steam bath attendance.

study_goal: The researchers were investigating the sources of Legionnaires' disease outbreaks, including a sauna, to identify and eliminate infection sources.
results_summary: The study identified a sauna as one of the sources of Legionella pneumophila infection in patients with lower respiratory disease. Swift diagnosis and source elimination were emphasized to prevent outbreaks.
population_specificity: Three male patients with lower respiratory disease (ages 51, 32, and 63).

study_goal: The researchers sought to determine the safety and efficacy of repeated 60°C sauna bathing in patients with chronic systolic congestive heart failure (CHF).
results_summary: Repeated sauna bathing was safe and improved symptoms, exercise tolerance, and cardiac function in CHF patients, with no adverse effects reported. It also reduced hospital admissions and improved biomarkers like plasma epinephrine and norepinephrine.
population_specificity: 15 hospitalized CHF patients (New York Heart Association class ≈ 2.8) in stable clinical condition on conventional treatments.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to study the physiological, therapeutic, and adverse effects of sauna bathing, particularly in chronic diseases, medication use, and special situations like pregnancy and childhood.
results_summary: Sauna was well tolerated with no significant health risks for healthy individuals, including those with stable hypertension, coronary heart disease, and congestive heart failure. It may relieve pain in musculoskeletal disorders, though antihypertensive medication could predispose to orthostatic hypotension post-bathing.
population_specificity: Healthy individuals, patients with chronic diseases (hypertension, coronary heart disease, congestive heart failure), pregnant women, and children.
effective_dosage: 5 to 20 minutes per session, repeated 1 to 3 times.
interactions: Antihypertensive medication may increase risk of orthostatic hypotension after bathing.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the mechanisms by which sauna therapy improves endothelial dysfunction in cardiomyopathic hamsters with chronic heart failure.
results_summary: Sauna therapy significantly increased aortic eNOS mRNA and protein expression and elevated serum nitrate concentrations in cardiomyopathic hamsters, suggesting improved endothelial function and nitric oxide production.
population_specificity: Male TO-2 cardiomyopathic hamsters with chronic heart failure.
effective_dosage: Daily 15-minute session at 39°C followed by 20 minutes at 30°C.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether repeated 60°C sauna treatment improves cardiac arrhythmias in chronic heart failure (CHF) patients.
results_summary: The study found that sauna treatment significantly reduced premature ventricular contractions (PVCs), improved heart rate variability, and decreased plasma brain natriuretic peptide concentrations in CHF patients compared to the non-treated group.
population_specificity: Thirty patients (59±3 years) with New York Heart Association functional class II or III CHF and at least 200 PVCs/24 h.
effective_dosage: Daily 60°C far infrared-ray dry sauna for 15 min, followed by 30 min bed rest with blankets, 5 days per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the therapeutic potential of sauna for patients with cardiovascular disease, particularly congestive heart failure.
results_summary: The study suggests promising data on sauna as a therapeutic modality for cardiovascular disease, but definitive conclusions are limited due to challenges in conducting double-blind, placebo-controlled studies.
population_specificity: Patients with cardiovascular disease, especially those with congestive heart failure.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether repeated sauna therapy reduces oxidative stress (measured by urinary 8-epi-PGF(2alpha) levels) and improves vascular endothelial function in patients with coronary risk factors.
results_summary: The study found that sauna therapy significantly reduced systolic blood pressure and urinary 8-epi-PGF(2alpha) levels compared to the non-sauna group, suggesting it may protect against oxidative stress and atherosclerosis.
population_specificity: 28 patients with at least one coronary risk factor.
effective_dosage: 60°C far infrared-ray dry sauna for 15 minutes, followed by 30 minutes of bed rest with a blanket, once daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the clinical and autonomic nervous system effects of complex sauna therapy in children with atopic dermatitis.
results_summary: Sauna therapy showed marked clinical improvement in children with atopic dermatitis and positively affected their autonomic nervous system, though long-term treatment was suggested for full autonomic regulation.
population_specificity: Children with atopic dermatitis

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the potential relevance of sauna use in the treatment of anorexia nervosa (AN) and its effects on hyperactivity, based on historical and animal model evidence.
results_summary: The study suggests that heat-treatment, including sauna sessions, may show progress in AN patients, possibly by addressing hyperactivity, but acknowledges the lack of reporting on sauna use in AN treatment strategies. The benefits of sauna may have been overlooked or attributed to conventional treatments.
population_specificity: Patients with anorexia nervosa (AN).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how 60°C sauna treatment improves cardiac function in patients with chronic heart failure (CHF) by examining its effects on endothelial function.
results_summary: Sauna treatment significantly improved endothelial function (%FMD), reduced BNP concentrations, and alleviated clinical symptoms in CHF patients, while no changes were observed in the control group.
population_specificity: 20 patients with NYHA class II or III CHF (aged 62 ± 15 years).
effective_dosage: 15 minutes in a 60°C sauna daily, followed by 30 minutes of bed rest.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the incidence and characteristics of sauna-related burns in Finland over a 7-year period.
results_summary: The study found that 25% of burn cases in the hospital were sauna-related, with 54% requiring surgery, 71% occurring in males, and 40% involving alcohol use. The estimated annual incidence was 7 burns per 100,000 people, equating to one hospitalization per day in Finland.
population_specificity: Burn patients treated at Kuopio University Hospital Burn Unit in Finland (n=598, with 154 sauna-related cases).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether exogenous reinfection of tuberculosis occurred in a high-risk environment (a day-laborers' facility with a sauna).
results_summary: The study found that two individuals at the same facility developed tuberculosis with similar RFLP patterns, suggesting exogenous reinfection from the first case. The sauna was mentioned as part of the facility but was not the focus of the study.
population_specificity: Day-laborers at a facility with a sauna.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to demonstrate a detoxification method using sauna and highlight the importance of an environmentally oriented medical history in treating chronic degenerative diseases.
results_summary: The patient experienced substantial symptom relief, discontinued all prior medications without adverse effects, and returned to employment. The study noted the release of solvents from the bloodstream and clinical improvement.
population_specificity: A single patient with a 20-year history of chronic multisystem disorder due to chemical sensitivity from workplace solvent exposure.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the hemodynamic effects of sauna therapy on blood pressure and peripheral circulation in hypertensive men during rest and different types of exercise.
results_summary: Sauna therapy significantly reduced systolic and diastolic blood pressure at rest and during dynamic exercise but not during isometric exercise. It also improved peripheral hemodynamics (muscle clearance and functional cross-section) during dynamic exercise.
population_specificity: 46 hypertensive men (WHO stages I-II, aged 41 ± 11 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of sauna therapy on blood pressure, heart frequency, peripheral hemodynamics, and cardiac function in patients with hypertension, coronary heart disease, and post-heart infarction aneurysm resection.
results_summary: Sauna therapy improved peripheral hemodynamics and blood pressure regulation in hypertensive patients but did not enhance left ventricular pumping function post-operation. All patient groups tolerated the therapy well.
population_specificity: Patients with hypertension, coronary heart disease (CHD), and those who underwent aneurysm resection after heart infarction.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the long-term effects of regular Finnish sauna use on blood pressure, heart frequency, and hemodynamics in patients with hypertension and coronary heart disease.
results_summary: Regular sauna use had a positive effect on blood pressure regulation and hemodynamics in hypertensive and coronary heart disease patients, comparable to the benefits observed with kinesiotherapy (running and swimming) in hypertensive patients.
population_specificity: Patients with hypertension, coronary heart disease, essential hypertension, and those who underwent aortocoronary venous-bypass operation (ACVB) (n = 65), compared to 68 hypertensive patients undergoing kinesiotherapy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate cardiovascular responses to isometric muscular exercise during sauna sessions in healthy men.
results_summary: The study measured cardiovascular responses during handgrip exercises before, during, and after sauna sessions, but specific outcomes were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Nine healthy men aged 26 to 46.
effective_dosage: 5-6 saunas with one-week intervals, each including 2-6 heatings of 8-15 minutes (80-85°C, 15% humidity).
study_duration: Multiple sessions over several weeks (exact total duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to study the effects of different heating and cooling treatments in a sauna on autonomic functions, particularly focusing on heart rate changes and their relaxing effects.
results_summary: The study found that controlled heating and cooling in a sauna had a relaxing effect, alleviating psycho-emotional stress, but noted that contrast-cooling (e.g., swimming after sauna use) may pose risks for individuals with unstable blood pressure.
population_specificity: Not specified (general population implied).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the potential role of hot, humid sauna exposure in triggering acute corneal hydrops in a patient with keratoconus.
results_summary: The study found that a healthy male with keratoconus developed acute corneal hydrops on two separate occasions after using a Finnish sauna, requiring surgical intervention. Histopathological examination confirmed breaks in Descemet's membrane and stromal edema.
population_specificity: A 44-year-old healthy male with bilateral keratoconus.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of sauna therapy on blood pressure, heart rate, and hemodynamics in hypertensive patients with IHD after ACVB surgery.
results_summary: The study found that sauna therapy significantly improved the left ventricular ejection fraction (by 7-8%) and peripheral microcirculation, but did not influence blood pressure after resting or during exercise.
population_specificity: 43 male untrained hypertensive patients with IHD after aortocoronary venous bypass surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy and tolerability of Saw Palmetto with Palmex®, finasteride, and tamsulosin in treating mild to moderate benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH).
results_summary: Saw Palmetto significantly improved maximum urinary flow (Qmax) by 23.1% and reduced IPSS scores by 74.6%, with comparable efficacy to other treatments. It also decreased prostate size and residual post-voiding volume, showing no significant differences in efficacy among the groups.
population_specificity: Men aged 40+ with mild to moderate BPH (IPSS score ≥1, <19).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether saw palmetto extract (SPE) improves urinary frequency-related quality of life in healthy Japanese adults aged ≥50 years without diagnosed benign prostatic hyperplasia or overactive bladder.
results_summary: After 12 weeks of SPE intervention, symptom bother from frequent urination significantly improved, and daytime urinary frequency decreased. SPE enhanced urinary frequency-related quality of life in the studied population.
population_specificity: Healthy Japanese adults aged ≥50 years without benign prostatic hyperplasia or overactive bladder.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the potential therapeutic mechanisms of saw palmetto in treating benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH), focusing on its active ingredients, targets, and pathways.
results_summary: The study identified 13 active components in saw palmetto, with stigmasterol as the core ingredient, and found that it inhibited BPH-1 cell viability and division by suppressing PGR, NCOA1, and NCOA2 expression. Molecular docking confirmed strong binding between stigmasterol and these hub genes, suggesting a therapeutic role in BPH treatment.
population_specificity: Geriatric male population with benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of a combination therapy (redensyl, saw palmetto, and biotin with PRP) against another treatment (Procapil with PRP) for androgenetic alopecia.
results_summary: The study found that PRP combined with redensyl, saw palmetto, and biotin showed significant improvement in AGA grading scores compared to the other treatment, suggesting it may be a better alternative.
population_specificity: 54 male patients with androgenetic alopecia attending a tertiary care hospital.
study_duration: Four sessions at three-week intervals (total duration not explicitly stated).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the safety and hemodynamic effects of a single sauna session in heart transplant patients during rehabilitation.
results_summary: The study found that a single sauna session was well tolerated, with significant decreases in blood pressure, improved microcirculation, increased left ventricular ejection fraction, and reduced total peripheral vascular resistance.
population_specificity: 8 male heart transplant patients (median age: 42 years) in rehabilitation phase III.
effective_dosage: Single sauna session (specific duration and temperature not specified).

study_goal: The abstract does not mention Spermidine or its study goals.
results_summary: The abstract does not discuss Spermidine or its effects.
population_specificity: Not specified (abstract focuses on lymphedema generally).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize recent advances in fluorescent methods for detecting polyamines like spermidine and highlight tumor-suppressing strategies involving polyamines.
results_summary: The study found that changes in polyamine concentrations can serve as biomarkers for cancer diagnosis and monitoring therapeutic effects. It also reviewed various fluorescent detection methods and tumor-suppressing strategies involving polyamines.
population_specificity: Not specified (general review of polyamine research)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the role of mitophagy in Alzheimer's disease and explore potential therapeutic benefits of mitophagy enhancers, including Spermidine.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific findings on Spermidine but discusses the broader context of mitophagy dysfunction in Alzheimer's disease and the potential of mitophagy enhancers to restore mitochondrial quality control.
population_specificity: Not specified (focus on Alzheimer's disease and mitochondrial dysfunction).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the role of polyamines, including spermidine, in SARS-CoV-2 infection and their potential impact on treatment effectiveness.
results_summary: The abstract suggests that polyamines like spermidine help maintain cell viability under harsh conditions and are involved in cell proliferation, differentiation, and growth, but it does not provide specific efficacy data for spermidine in COVID-19.
population_specificity: Not specified (general review of polyamines in cellular and viral contexts).

study_goal: To determine the effect of longer-term spermidine supplementation on memory performance and biomarkers in older adults with subjective cognitive decline.
results_summary: The study found no significant changes in memory performance or biomarkers after 12 months of spermidine supplementation compared to placebo. Exploratory analyses suggested possible benefits for verbal memory and inflammation, but these findings require further validation.
population_specificity: Adults aged 60-90 years with subjective cognitive decline.
effective_dosage: 0.9 mg spermidine per day, extracted from wheat germ.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate anticancer strategies targeting polyamine metabolism, including spermidine, and assess the potential of combination therapies and natural active ingredients.
results_summary: The study suggests that targeting polyamine metabolism is a rational anticancer strategy, with combination therapies and natural bioactive substances showing promise due to their synergistic effects and ability to affect multiple targets. Polyamine metabolic enzymes are identified as important therapeutic targets.
population_specificity: Not specified (general discussion of polyamines in cancer cells).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate translational approaches for inhibiting EIF5A hypusination in pathogenic parasites and therapy-resistant tumors, assessing its potential for Advanced Medicinal Therapies.
results_summary: The abstract highlights the importance of spermidine in cell proliferation and its role in EIF5A hypusination, but notes limited translational application of inhibitors in murine models. It suggests potential for treating drug-resistant cancers and parasitic infections but lacks detailed efficacy data.
population_specificity: Pathogenic parasites and therapy-resistant tumors (murine models mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the role of polyamines, including spermidine, in tumor microenvironment regulation and their potential as therapeutic targets, particularly in enhancing antitumor immune responses.
results_summary: The study highlights that polyamines like spermidine influence tumor-permissive microenvironments and immune responses, potentially contributing to immunologically "cold" tumors. It also suggests that microbiota composition and dietary polyamine availability can alter polyamine metabolism and function in cancer contexts.
population_specificity: Not specified (focus on general mechanisms in cancer and immune response).
